text: In optics the noise-equivalent flux density (NEFD) or noise-equivalent irradiance (NEI) of a system is the level of flux density required to be equivalent to the noise present in the system. It is a measure used by astronomers in determining the accuracy of observations. The NEFD can be related to a light detector's Noise-equivalent power for a collection area A and a photon bandwidth u by: NEFD = \eta \frac{NEP}{A u}, where a factor \eta (often 2, in the case of switching between measuring a source and measuring off-source) accounts for the photon statistics for the mode of operation. ==References== Category:Physical quantities Category:Vector calculus
title: Noise-equivalent flux density
